title: gulp -- completion=zsh returns an error exit code if no gulpfile
body:
When adding the following line to my `.zshrc`:

``` sh
eval "$(gulp --completion=zsh)"
```

I'm getting the following error on my terminal login:

``` sh
/usr/local/lib/node_modules/gulp/bin/gulp:11
  throw new Error("Missing Gulpfile");
        ^
Error: Missing Gulpfile
    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/gulp/bin/gulp:11:9)
    at Module._compile (module.js:456:26)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:474:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:312:12)
    at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:497:10)
    at startup (node.js:119:16)
    at node.js:902:3
```

This happens to due the faulty evaluation of `$(gulp --tasks-simple)`.

This can be caught in my shell login (`2> /dev/null`) but I don't see any reason why gulp should return an error code on the completions.

I take the grunt completions for example, even if you're outside the scope of a `Gruntfile.js` you'll still get no error evaluating `grunt --version --verbose`. (and thus get no error exit code on the shell eval for grunt completions)

In fact, if you try running `gulp --version` outside of a `gulpfile.js` project scope you'll also get the same "Missing Gulpfile" error which makes no sense.

This obviously focuses on getting a correct exit code from the `gulp --completion=zsh` eval but I think a functionality of `gulp --version` outside of any project scope should always work if you install gulp globally.
